At that time, the Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, attain four kinds of vast and superior qualities due to the power of their wholesome roots.
What are the four?

First, they quickly enter into all wholesome dharmas; second, they are praised by Dharma teachers; third, their practice is complete and free from transgression; fourth, they uphold the true Dharma of the Buddha without destruction.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are the four kinds of vast and superior qualities attained by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
Because of this power, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, even while in the human realm, attain four more kinds of vast and superior qualities.
What are the four?
First, for the sake of many sentient beings, they follow and cultivate, ultimately abiding in all wholesome dharmas;
Second, on level roads they build inns that are extremely solid and dense, quickly causing sentient beings to attain joy;
Third, for a long time they obtain the benefits of the Dharma, and their joyful mind does not diminish;
Fourth, at the end of life, without a mind entangled in delusion, they are reborn in a good destiny, a blissful world.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's obtaining four kinds of vast and superior methods while dwelling among humans.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, by virtue of this power, while dwelling among the gods obtains four more kinds of vast and superior methods.
What are the four?
First, because of the blessings they have cultivated, they are able to gather the heavenly multitudes;
Second, when the gods assemble, they gaze up at the gateway of their face, thinking:
'What will the bodhisattva expound now?
Having heard it, we will have an awakening.'
Third, for the sake of the Heavenly King Åšakra and other celestial sons who come to consult and request the Dharma to resolve doubts, but the bodhisattva does not go to them.
Fourth, manifesting a great palace for the bodhisattvas to enjoy and make use of.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are the four kinds of vast and superior Dharma that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain while dwelling in the heavens.
ÅšÄriputra!

In this way, when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, whether in the heavens or born among humans, they attain innumerable, boundless hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of marvelous Dharma doors, all in order to fulfill the perfection of morality.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The bodhisattva sits on a high seat, revered by the devas,
Gazing up at the venerable face, about to proclaim what Dharma?
All respectfully endowed with wisdom, eliminating stinginess and greed,
Dwelling in the Palace of Joy, Indra comes to invite, with doubts.
When the lifespan in the heavens is exhausted, one is reborn among humans,
Becoming a wheel-turning sage king, with great power and no stinginess.
If one ends one's life among humans and is reborn in the heavens again,
Never experiencing various sufferings, it is because one served the Dharma teacher.
One always obtains these four kinds of vast and excellent abodes,
Without a lowly mind, respectfully serving those who expound the Dharma.
If one respectfully and lovingly offers a water vessel,
One will be revered and served by devas, nÄgas, and humans.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, accomplish such wholesome roots, and further obtain four dharmas in the heavens.
What are the four?
First, knowing the karma created in past lives;
Second, they know that because of this goodness they are reborn in the heavens, and they can also know the loss of good dharmas;
Third, they know that from here they will end their life and be reborn in such and such a place;
Fourth, for the sake of the heavenly multitudes they expound the wonderful Dharma, showing, teaching, and delighting them. Having thus benefited them, they then abandon the heavenly body.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the four dharmas that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain when reborn in the heavens, all due to the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, because they accomplish these roots of goodness, they attain four kinds of perfectly accomplished supreme dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!
What are the four?
First, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having abandoned the heavenly palaces, return to the human realm and are born together with morality.
Second, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, dwelling among humans, attain five kinds of supremely accomplished dharmas.
What are the five?

Namely, being born in an excellent family, obtaining excellent appearance, obtaining excellent pure precepts, obtaining excellent retinue, and being able to cultivate excellent loving-kindness towards sentient beings. These are called the five kinds of excellent dharmas that are attained.
Third, when Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are among humans, they further attain five kinds of indestructible dharmas.
What are the five?

Namely, being able to obtain indestructible good spiritual friends, the body that is received will never die prematurely, the wealth and status that are obtained will never decline, the bodhicitta that is obtained cannot be destroyed, and when the Dharma is lacking, one can obtain sufficiency for oneself. These are called the five kinds of indestructible dharmas that are attained.
Fourth, when Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are among humans, they further attain five kinds of rare and perfect dharmas.
What are the five?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas set up empty vessels in their houses. Wherever their hands reach, all kinds of precious treasures will fill up.
This is called the first attainment of a rare and perfect Dharma.
When a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva encounters thirst, a pool with the eight virtues naturally appears before him. This is called the second attainment of a rare and perfect Dharma.

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's body is sustained by merit and is not harmed by external things, namely poison, weapons, fire, water, those who suck vital energy, or evil yaká¹£as and ghosts, which cannot harm him. This is called the third attainment of a rare and perfect Dharma.

When the various calamities and kalpas arise in JambudvÄ«pa, namely the kalpa of swords, the kalpa of famine, the kalpa of disease, the kalpa of fire, the kalpa of water, the kalpa of wind, the kalpa of thirst, the kalpa of hot light, or the kalpa of yaká¹£as,
ÅšÄriputra!

When such a separate kalpa arises, at that time the bodhisattva is not born in it, but instead is born in the heavens and experiences the utmost bliss and much extreme happiness. This is called the fourth attainment of a rare and perfect Dharma.

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, by the power of such wholesome roots, is never again born in places of difficulty, is not born in evil destinies, and if the mind is entangled in regret, he is able to see and know it and quickly distances himself from it. This is called the fifth attainment of a rare and perfect Dharma.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the four kinds of rare and perfect supreme Dharmas that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains by practicing the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing the perfection of morality, accomplishes these wholesome roots and thus is always not separated from four kinds of wonderful Dharmas.
What are the four?
First, when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas only see sentient beings suffering, they immediately attain a mind of great compassion;
Second, all the sons and daughters of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas respectfully follow the bodhisattva;
Third, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to control aging and are not harmed by it;
Fourth, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas obtain a hundred times, or even two or three times more, the benefits of their livelihood and work.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is the four kinds of wonderful dharmas that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always do not part with when practicing the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality and accomplish these wholesome roots, they are not robbed by three dharmas.
What are the three?
First, they are not robbed by greed and desire; second, they are not robbed by anger and hatred; third, they are not robbed by ignorance and delusion.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality!
They are far removed from the three kinds of robbery and theft.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, because they accomplish these wholesome roots, they attain four kinds of illness-free dharmas.
What are the four?

First, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not afflicted by long-term illnesses; second, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have fresh and lustrous limbs and have never been emaciated; third, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' resources and necessities are not diminished; fourth, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not harmed or injured by kings, thieves, evil people, or other beings.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice of the perfection of morality, and therefore obtaining the four kinds of methods for attaining health.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, practicing the perfection of morality, because of accomplishing these wholesome roots, obtains the four kinds of marks of a venerable position.
What are the four?

First, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, as a wheel-turning king, with authority over the four realms, rules the world with the Dharma, called the Dharma King, with the seven treasures coming and responding, all fully accomplished.
What are the seven?

Namely, the treasure of the wheel, the treasure of the elephant, the treasure of the horse, the treasure of the woman, the treasure of the jewel, the treasure of the householder, and the treasure of the military commander.
With a full thousand sons, their appearance upright and majestic, with heroic power subduing enemies.

This wheel-turning king is the object of reverence and submission by the four continents, and is also guarded by prime ministers, ministers, and the assembly of the country's people and various minor kings.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the first honored position obtained by a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not attached to the five desires, namely, forms cognized by the eyes, sounds cognized by the ears, smells cognized by the nose, tastes cognized by the tongue, and tactile objects cognized by the body.

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not attached to these five desires, with pure faith they leave home and enter the path, quickly attaining the five supernormal knowledges, and are respected by humans and non-humans.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the second honored position obtained by a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
ÅšÄriputra!
Wherever bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are born,
They will naturally always attain the supreme enlightenment, the supreme wisdom, and the supreme eloquence, and be respected by the great kings.

Just as in the past world, the great crow-headed one was respected by the king, and this bodhisattva is also like this, respected by the king, invited to ascend to the throne, and also by the prime minister, the ministers, the guards, the assembly, the country, and the people, who all respect and admire him.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the third characteristic of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's attainment of the honored position.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

After the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has realized supreme, perfect enlightenment, his majestic virtue is exceptionally victorious and perfectly supreme. He is respected by all beings, such as devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans.
Why is this?

By this, the bodhisattva attains the most excellent aspects of morality, concentration, and wisdom, and the aspects of liberation and the knowledge and vision of liberation. Because he realizes purity in these dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's attainment of the fourth aspect of a superior position.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice of the perfection of morality, whereby he attains four aspects of a superior position, all for the sake of fulfilling the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

In this way, when the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices the perfection of morality, he attains immeasurable and limitless wonderful dharmas of merit by means of a pure mind, due to offering a water vessel to the two venerable teachers, the upÄdhyÄya and ÄcÄrya.

Namely, because the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva seeks the Dharma, he goes and comes, advances and stops, in accordance with the teacher. As he says, he never goes against him. Because he accomplishes such wholesome roots and power, he further obtains four kinds of supreme wealth.
What are the four?
First, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is born into a place where he obtains the wealth used by a great king, not the inferior equipment of other beings.

Second, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is born into a place where he receives the Dharma of detachment and obtains the wealth of an immortal. With pure faith, he abandons the home life and enters the Way, which is called the wealth of the holy Dharma.
Third, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is born into a place where he obtains the recollection of past lives, which is called obtaining the wealth of recollection.
Because of this recollection, in every life he never forgets the mind of enlightenment.

Fourth, after the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains supreme perfect enlightenment, it is called the wealth of enlightenment, and he is always surrounded in front and back by the fourfold assembly, devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the four kinds of supreme wealth that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains by practicing the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices the perfection of morality, he goes and comes, advances and stops in accordance with the teachings and instructions of the Dharma teacher, up to the one who upholds even just four lines of verse, saying 'this is good, this is not good, this has faults, this is without faults, this should be practiced, this should not be practiced.'
Moreover, such teachings, up to the completion of this matter, are able to bring about meaninglessness, unprofitableness, and the dharmas of suffering and distress in the long night.
If one does this, in the long night one will be able to give rise to meaningful and beneficial dharmas of peace and happiness.
Such teachings, following the master's instructions, do not create unwholesomeness, but cultivate wholesome dharmas, without contradiction or opposition.
Because of this, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, by accomplishing such wholesome roots, further attains four kinds of lofty and superior dharmas.
What are the four?

First, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains the lofty and superior dharma of possessing moral discipline; second, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's body and all its parts are completely perfect; third, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains great wisdom, emerging wisdom, lofty wisdom, vast wisdom, swift wisdom, sharp wisdom, quick wisdom, profound wisdom, and the wisdom of discernment; fourth, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when the body perishes and life ends, is reborn in the good destinies, the realms of the devas.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the four kinds of superior qualities that a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains when practicing the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, because they accomplish such roots of goodness, they also attain four kinds of unobservable dharmas.
What are the four?
ÅšÄriputra!
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas accomplish such roots of goodness, wherever they are born, they will naturally attain the hidden male organ, which is called the first unobservable dharma.
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, due to the power of such wholesome roots, from the time of their birth, whether it be their mother, father, other relatives, gods, dragons, yaká¹£as, rÄká¹£asas, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, or any other sentient beings, with either pure or defiled minds, none can see the crown of the Bodhisattva's head. ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, due to the power of such wholesome roots, from the time of their birth, whether it be their mother, father, or any other sentient beings, including humans and non-humans, with either pure or defiled minds, none can adorn the Bodhisattva's face.
Those who gaze upon it, if they give rise to the thought:
I shall adorn the Bodhisattva's face, then the reflection of the face will appear on their two feet.
Why is this?
ÅšÄriputra!

Because this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has accomplished such rare and wonderful dharmas, he is called a good man, and he has also accomplished the most excellent and supreme eloquence of a man. This is called the third unobservable dharma.
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, because they have accomplished such wholesome roots, when they are first born, without being supported by anyone, they stand on the ground and look in all four directions, and immediately attain sharp and keen wisdom.
Why is this?
Because this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva in past lives sought to hear the Dharma with a sincere mind.

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has also attained eyes free from deceit and flattery. Because he has accomplished these eyes free from deceit and flattery, his pure divine eye surpasses that of humans, and he is able to see all sentient beings in the trichiliocosm.

Moreover, this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains swift and vast wisdom. Due to the accomplishment of this vast wisdom, he is able to understand the minds accumulated by all sentient beings in the three times.
Why is this?

Because this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when seeking the Dharma in the past, focused his mind with intention and made diligent respectful efforts. Toward the true Dharma, he gave rise to the thought of it being a fine medicine, the thought of it being a precious treasure, the thought of it being difficult to encounter, and the thought of it being excellent and good. As he contemplated, he sought to hear the true Dharma. Having heard it, he upheld it.

Because of this, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva further attains the wisdom of swift discernment. Due to the accomplishment of this wisdom of discernment, he is well able to weigh the precepts of sentient beings, and is well able to weigh their correct hearing, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation.

Moreover, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are well able to measure the same nature of the precepts of all sentient beings, and are well able to measure the same nature of right hearing, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation.ğŸ”½Moreover, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are well able to measure the outflow of the precepts of all sentient beings, and are well able to measure the outflow of right hearing, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation.

Moreover, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are well able to measure the characteristics of the outflow of the precepts of all sentient beings that surpass [those of others], and are well able to measure the characteristics of the outflow of right hearing, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation that surpass [those of others].
Moreover, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are well able to measure the characteristics of the progress, conduct, practice, and vigor of all sentient beings.
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having thus gradually measured and contemplated the merits of all sentient beings, think like this:

'The precepts, learning, and even liberation and the knowledge and insight of liberation possessed by these sentient beings, the same nature of precepts, and even the same nature of right learning, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation possessed by these sentient beings,ğŸ”½the outflow of precepts, and even the outflow of right learning, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation possessed by these sentient beings,

the superior characteristics of the outflow of precepts, and even the superior characteristics of the outflow of right learning, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation possessed by these sentient beings,
the characteristics of the progress, conduct, practice, and courageous conduct of these sentient beings, such characteristics are all the merits possessed by sentient beings.
I now measure and contemplate among them, and do not see anyone who is equal to myself.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought:
'The fundamental nature of all sentient beings is firmly established. When I compare myself to them, I do not see anyone who is equal to me.'
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
When the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva was first born, in an instant he was able to quickly give rise to the wondrous wisdom of karmic retribution.
By means of this wisdom, in the time of a single finger snap, he was able to understand the one thousand kinds of mental characteristics of all sentient beings.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva used his wisdom to contemplate all these minds, and he did not see anyone who was equal to himself.

The Bodhisattva MahÄsattva had such correct understanding: 'I am now alone in the supreme and honored position, like a lion king dwelling fearlessly, like a great nÄga king with great majestic virtue.'

His feet did not touch the ground as he walked seven steps in each direction. He contemplated the wondrous karmic retribution of the seat of enlightenment, dwelling in the present and proclaiming these words:ğŸ”½'I am the most honored and great one in the world.
I am the most distinguished in the world.
I will now realize the end of birth, old age, and death.
I will liberate all sentient beings from birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.
I will proclaim for all sentient beings the vast, subtle, supreme, unsurpassed true Dharma.'
ÅšÄriputra!
When the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva utters these words, there is no interruption, and the sound completely fills this trichiliocosm.
The sentient beings within it, upon hearing this sound, are frightened and their hair stands on end. The heavenly drum trembles and emits a great sound many times.
And this world is all shaken, but only the ground where the Bodhisattva resides, as much as the area of a chariot wheel, remains still and quiet.
Below this earth wheel, it rests on a mass of water, which is also not shaken by that great wind.

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes his own body and sees immeasurable light pervading the body, and then realizes anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. He is looked up to by all sentient beings. This is called the fourth unobservable dharma.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the four kinds of unobservable dharmas obtained by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Why is it so?
It is all because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the past, when practicing the perfection of morality, followed the Dharma master's coming and going, and obeyed his teachings without disobedience.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, having accomplished these wholesome roots, they further attain four kinds of swift dharmas.
What are the four?

When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain Buddhahood, they will be endowed with these. The Dharma spoken by all Buddhas and TathÄgatas will be complete without deficiency, and the Dharma they speak will be without empty verbiage.
This is called the first swift Dharma.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain Buddhahood, they will be endowed with these. If all Buddhas and TathÄgatas have something to command, they will say:
'Come forth, bhiká¹£us.
' At that time, sentient beings will then come to the Buddha, their hair will automatically fall out, they will don the kaá¹£Äya robe, and hold the alms bowl.
This is called the second swift Dharma.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain Buddhahood, they will be endowed with these. All Buddhas and TathÄgatas will skillfully know the three periods of sentient beings' minds.
This is called the third swift Dharma.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain Buddhahood, they will be endowed with these. All Buddhas and TathÄgatas will skillfully know the wisdom of sentient beings' illnesses and medicines.
This is called the fourth swift Dharma.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the four kinds of swift dharmas obtained by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Why is it so?
It is because in the past, when practicing the perfection of morality, they offered water vessels to upÄdhyÄyas, ÄcÄryas, and Dharma teachers with a pure mind.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, relying on the perfection of morality and possessing such wholesome roots, when they attain Buddhahood, will obtain four kinds of unharmable dharmas.
What are the four?
ÅšÄriputra!
The body of the TathÄgata is without support and without reception.
Why is it so?
If the body of the TathÄgata were to be harmed by fire, weapons, poison, or other things, it would be impossible.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the four kinds of unharmable dharmas obtained by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas when they attain Buddhahood due to possessing morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas rely on the perfection of morality. Due to possessing such wholesome roots, when they attain Buddhahood they will again attain four kinds of unsurpassed dharmas.
What are the four?
First, the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones have no dependence and no support.
Why is this?
There are no sentient beings who can say in front of the TathÄgata:
I will speak for the TathÄgata a Dharma that has not been heard, even a single phrase.
If one can speak it, there is no such possibility.
Second, the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones have no dependence and no support.
Why is this?
There are no sentient beings who can establish a discourse according to the Dharma in front of the TathÄgata, even a single phrase.
If one can establish a discourse, there is no such possibility.
Third, the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones have no dependence and no support.
Why is this?
There are no sentient beings who can attain even a tiny portion of the TathÄgata's undetermined mind.
If one can attain it, there is no such possibility.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
The minds of all buddhas and tathÄgatas are always in samÄdhi, because they abide in loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
Fourth, all buddhas and tathÄgatas have no dependence and no support.
Why is it so?
There are no sentient beings who can grasp the physical characteristics of the TathÄgata.
If one tries to grasp characteristics, there is no such possibility.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because all buddhas and tathÄgatas are endowed with precepts, they attain four kinds of unsurpassed dharmas.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
All buddhas and tathÄgatas, by accomplishing the power of such wholesome roots, attain the perfection of five immeasurable dharmas.
What are the five?

First, the precepts of all buddhas and tathÄgatas are immeasurable; second, the right hearing of all buddhas and tathÄgatas is immeasurable; third, the right samÄdhi of all buddhas and tathÄgatas is immeasurable; fourth, the right wisdom of all buddhas and tathÄgatas is immeasurable; fifth, the liberation and the knowledge and vision of liberation of all buddhas and tathÄgatas are immeasurable.
ÅšÄriputra!

In this way, the TathÄgata's five immeasurable dharmas all come from the past when he was practicing the perfection of morality. At that time, he followed the teachings of his preceptors and teachers, and his comings and goings were without contradiction.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, having perfected the perfection of morality, by the power of having accomplished such wholesome roots, have attained four kinds of unobstructed wisdom.
What are the four?
It is said that the World-Honored Buddhas have unobstructed wisdom and insight that turns in the past.
The World-Honored Buddhas have unobstructed wisdom and insight that turns in the future.
The World-Honored Buddhas have unobstructed wisdom and insight that turns in the present.
The World-Honored Buddhas are well able to give rise to an impartial mind. By giving rise to such an impartial mind, they are able to know the nature of equality in the three times.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the TathÄgata's attainment of the four kinds of unobstructed wisdom due to being fully endowed with moral discipline.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also well able to accomplish right wisdom. Due to right wisdom, they do not rely on others and are able to know all dharmas.
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also able to accomplish inconceivable wisdom. Due to accomplishing this inconceivable wisdom, they are able to understand the characteristics of wind and rain.
ÅšÄriputra!
